bullets.text: U.S. productivity rose 4.9% (Q3 2025) while unit labor costs fell 1.9%, improving inflation backdrop and corporate margin potential.
U.S. trade deficit surged in November 2025 despite tariffs, signaling persistent import demand and limited near-term rebalancing from trade policy.
Apartment rents fell to the lowest level in four years, adding disinflation pressure to shelter components that heavily influence CPI.
Markets focused on imminent Fed chair pick; prediction markets also price near-certainty of no January 2026 rate change.
U.S. weighs expanded military options and force buildup near Iran, raising regional escalation risk and potential energy-market volatility.
Trump claims Putin agreed to a weeklong pause in attacks during extreme cold; durability of any de-escalation remains uncertain.
Venezuela approved sweeping oil-sector overhaul aimed at restructuring participation and investment terms; U.S. airline service also resumes, hinting at tentative normalization.
AI-driven hardware demand is tightening memory supply; PC and smartphone component costs may rise, reinforcing semiconductor outperformance versus software.
Big Tech diverged: Apple reported surging iPhone demand, while Microsoft suffered its largest drop since 2020, underscoring earnings sensitivity to AI spending narratives.
Amazon reportedly explores up to $50B investment in OpenAI; broader IPO chatter (OpenAI, SpaceX) signals accelerating capital markets cycle for frontier AI/space firms.
Autonomous-vehicle safety scrutiny intensifies as NHTSA investigates a Waymo robotaxi hitting a child, potentially slowing regulatory approvals and commercial rollout pace.
Science highlights: blood test may detect Parkinson’s years early; new process converts exhaust CO2 into useful materials, supporting lower-cost screening and carbon utilization.
